description: Unknown. Perhaps a blend of squash +‎ quell +‎ quench. Compare also English squolsh, English squoosh.

entries.meaning: (radio technology) The suppression of the unwanted hiss or static between received transmissions by adjusting the gain of the receiver.
(countable, dated) A heavy blow or fall.
(countable, music) A kind of electronic beat or sound mainly used in acid house and related music genres.
examples: Through a process of experimentation the 'acid squelch' sound came forth, which was recorded and passed on to DJ Ron Hardy to play at his Warehouse club.

verbs.description: squelch (third-person singular simple present squelches, present participle squelching, simple past and past participle squelched)

entries.meaning: (transitive, US) To halt, stop, eliminate, stamp out, or put down, often suddenly or by force.
examples: Even the king's announcement could not squelch the rumors.

entries.meaning: (transitive, radio technology) To suppress the unwanted hiss or static between received transmissions by adjusting a threshold level for signal strength.
(intransitive, Britain) To make a sucking, splashing noise as when walking on muddy ground.
examples: The mud squelched underfoot; it had been raining all night.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Britain) To walk or step through a substance such as mud.
examples: The mud was thick and sticky underfoot, but we squelched through it nonetheless.
